statement:
Let $D\subset \mathbb R^2$ be an open set and let $\omega$ be a
differential form defined on $D$.

If $D$ is simply connected and $\omega$ is a closed differential form,
then $\omega$ is an exact differential form.

The proof of this result is a consequence of the following useful
lemmas.

Let $\omega$ be a closed differential form and suppose that $\gamma_0$
and $\gamma_1$ are two regular homotopic curves in $D$ (with the same
end points). Then $$\int_{\gamma_0} \omega = \int_{\gamma_1}\omega.$$

Let $\omega$ be a continuous differential form. If given any two curves
$\gamma_0$, $\gamma_1$ in $D$ with the same end-points, it holds
$$\int_{\gamma_0} \omega = \int_{\gamma_1} \omega,$$ then $\omega$ is
exact.

See the Poincaré Lemma for a generalization of this result on
$n$-dimensional manifolds.
names: closed differential forms on a simply connected domain
